interactives.title: Atom Data Table
interactives.subtitle: One way to display a table of atom properties.
about: There are three parts in this Interactive that work together to create the atom data table example.

1. Separate outputs are created for each datum to be represented in the table. The result is that the name values for these outputs can later be used for any component that can accept a model property.
2. numericOutput compnents are created for each of the output properties. All the numericOutput components are given the same width in 'ems'.
3. text components are created to make the row and column labels. The text components are given widths to match the rest of the values in that column.
The performance of this manual method for creating a table is not as high as if we made a custom table component.
atomToolTips are enabled in this Interactive, hover over an atom to display a tooltip, shift-click on an atom to make that tooltip persistent.

interactives.title: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Melting Experiment
about: Specific heat capacity is the measure of the heat energy required
to raise the temperature of a given quantity of a substance by one
kelvin. Latent heat of melting describes tœhe amount of heat
required to melt a solid. When a solid is undergoing melting, the
temperature basically remains constant until the entire solid is
molten. The above simulation demonstrates the specific heat and
the latent heat.
The physical origin of latent heat is that when a system is in a
phase transition, its structure will change. Changing structure
usually results in changes of potential energy, because potential
energy depends primarily on structure. In the simulation,
the energy added to the system is absorbed by the atoms and used
to break the interatomic interactions (so that they can leave the
condensed state). During the phase transition the kinetic energy
doesn't increase, as the
potential energy increases in the expense of the input energy.
During this period, the interatomic interactions diminish and the
structure breaks up, resulting in a phase transition.
One thing you would notice is that the temperature-energy curve on
the right has fluctuations. This is because we have much fewer
atoms (169) in the simulation than there would be in a real
physical model.

interactives.title: Amino Acids Momentum Test
about: A simple test checking whether the total momentum of each molecule (amino acids chain)
is always equal to zero.
Amino acids in water or oil are pushed toward the molecule center of mass or in the opposite
direction (it depends on the hydrophobicity of the amino acids). In most cases the sum of
these forces would be different from zero and would cause a confusing movement of the molecule.
They would drift and collide with boundaries.
To avoid this effect, Next Gen MW modifies velocities of each particle to ensure that the
total momentum of the whole molecule is always equal to zero.
That's why you can observe that each molecule holds its initial position.

interactives.title: Dielectric Constant
about: An interactive presenting the dielectric effect and its influence on Coulomb forces. The graph plots two variables:
- distance between particles (in nanometers),
- **effective** value of the dielectric constant (*).
What does **effective** mean in the context of dielectric constant?
Next Gen MW uses a special algorithm for calculation of the dielectric effect.
When particles are close enough to each other, it assumes that the screening effect
of the solvent (oil or water) should be diminished. That's why you can observe that
the effective dielectric constant is significantly reduced when particles are closer
than 1.2nm to each other.
The effective dielectric constant for Coulomb interaction of two particles is
calculated using following equation:
**effectiveDC = 1 + (DC - 1)/(1 + exp(-12 * R + 7))**
where **DC** is an initial dielectric constant for solvent (e.g. 10 for water)
and **R** is the distance between particles.
You can disable this algorithm and leave the value of the dielectric constant
untouched (so, **effectiveDC = DC**) using the **Realistic Dielectric Effect** checkbox.
_Note that the effectiveDielectric output property defined in the interactive JSON does
**not** ask the model about the effective value, as it's unavailable in Scripting API
and hidden deeply in the engine internals. Instead, it recalculates effective dielectric
constant using the same algorithm like the engine._

interactives.title: Temperature sensors (bar graphs)
interactives.subtitle: Why does a warm object feel warm when you touch it?
interactives.about:
The model shows two contacting objects that have identical mass (*m*)
and specific heat (*c*<sub>p</sub>) but different initial temperatures.
The amount of heat transferred between them measures the heat initially
stored in the warmer object.

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary. Click on a thermometer to highlight
    its data.
4.  Wait until the temperatures of the two objects do not change any
    further.
5.  Record the final temperature of the two objects in your workbook.

**Click the Reset button** and change the initial temperatures of the
two objects using the drop-down menus below the model. Repeat steps 1-5
for two more different temperature setups.

interactives.title: Heat Storage 1A: Measuring heat storage
interactives.subtitle: Why does a warm object feel warm when you touch it?
about: The model shows two contacting objects that have identical mass (*m*)
and specific heat (*c*p) but different initial temperatures.
The amount of heat transferred between them measures the heat initially
stored in the warmer object.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  Wait until the temperatures of the two objects do not change any further.
3.  Note the final temperature of the two objects.
Reset the model and change the initial temperatures of the two
objects using the sliders below the model. Repeat steps 1-3
for two more different temperature setups.

interactives.title: Heat Storage 1B: Heat storage depends on specific heat
interactives.subtitle: Why do some materials take longer to heat up or cool down than others?
about: How much heat is stored in an object depends on its specific heat, as described by the formula below:
*Q* = **c**p⋅**m**(*T*final-*T*initial)
This model is similar to 1A, except that the specific heats of the two rectangular objects are different.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  Wait until the temperatures of the two objects do not change any further.
3.  Note the final temperature of the two objects.
Reset the model and change the specific heats of the two
objects using the sliders below the model. Repeat steps 1-3 for
two more different setups. Make sure that the specific heats are
different in each setup.

interactives.title: Heat Storage 1C: Heat storage depends on size
interactives.subtitle: Why does a bigger house need more energy to heat?
about: How much heat stored in an object depends on its mass, or size, as described by the formula below:
**Q** = *c*p⋅**m**(*T*final - *T*initial)
**Note:** that the specific heats of the two rectangular objects are different. Your task is to change the size of one or both
objects—hence the mass—so that the equilibrium temperature will be approximately 25°C.
1.  To change the size of an object, click and drag the small yellow rectangles at its edges.
2.  **Make sure that the objects still touch each other but do not overlap and there is a thermometer in each object.**
3.  Run the model and wait until the temperatures do not change any further.
4.  If the final temperatures are close to 25°C (within 1°C), note the sizes of the objects.
5.  Otherwise, Reset the model, resize the objects, and run the model again until the final temperatures
are close to 25°C (within 1°C).
You may use the grid and the ruler as visual assistance when you drag the rectangles.
Use the drop-down menu under the model to change to a different setup of
specific heats and repeat the task.

interactives.title: Power and Energy 2A: Regulating temperature
interactives.subtitle: Why does the temperature in a box change more dramatically than the temperature in the other?
about: Two closed boxes have identical heaters but the heat capacity of the left-hand box is much greater
than the heat capacity of the right-hand box. The power switch controls both heaters.
1. Run the model and use the graph to monitor the temperatures.
When the **left-hand side box** reaches 5°C, turn off the power.
2. Try to keep the temperature in the **left-hand side box** between
3 and 5°C by turning the power on and off.
3. Compare the shapes of the two temperature curves.

interactives.title: Conduction 3A: Heat conduction through materials
interactives.subtitle: Which material conducts heat most quickly?
about: In this model, you will compare heat conduction through four different types of materials: metal, stone, fiberglass, and wood.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the four thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Rescale the graph if necessary
4.  Wait until the temperatures do not change any further.
5.  In which material does heat flow the fastest?

interactives.title: Conduction 3B: The effect of thermal conductivity
interactives.subtitle: Which test piece has higher thermal conductivity?
about: The rate of heat conduction depends on the thermal conductivity of the material (*k*), as described in the formula below:
(This formula says that heat transfer rate is proportional to thermal conductivity.)
This model has two situations for you to compare. On the left are two separate heat sources with a
constant temperature (50°C). On the right are two separate objects with a thermometer, which
measures how much heat has been conducted. The left-hand side and right-hand side objects are
connected by two test pieces that differ in only thermal conductivity (*k*). **Your task is to
tell which test piece has higher thermal conductivity.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.

interactives.title: Conduction 3C: The effect of wall thickness
interactives.subtitle: Which wall loses thermal energy more quickly, thick or thin?
about: The rate of heat conduction depends on how far heat has to travel (*L*), as described below:
(This formula says that the heat transfer rate is *inversely* proportional to the distance heat has to travel.)
This model has two situations for you to compare. On the left are two separate heat sources with a constant temperature.
On the right are two separate objects with a thermometer that measures how much heat has been conducted. The upper test
piece is twice as long as the lower one. Both are made of the same material. This would be like a thick wall compared to a thin one.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.

interactives.title: Conduction 3D: The effect of temperature difference
interactives.subtitle: Does a hotter object lose heat more quickly?
about: **Your task is to investigate how the amount of heat conducted through the test piece depends on the temperature of the heater on the left-hand side:**
1.  Run the model until it stops (it will automatically stop after 30 minutes of model time).
2.  Note the change of the temperature over time in the graph.
3.  Write down the temperature of the heater and the temperature of the thermometer when the model stops.
4.  Use the drop-down menu below the model to change the heater temperature.
5.  Repeat 1-3 for two more different heater temperatures.

interactives.title: Conduction 3E: Combine conductivity and heat capacity
interactives.subtitle: Which material provides the best insulation?
about: In this model, there are three test pieces made of materials that have different thermal conductivities and heat capacities.
**Your task is to find out which material is the best insulator.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the three thermometers.
2.  Choose **Thermal energy** from the **Heat map** drop-down list to switch the view from temperature distribution to thermal energy distribution.

In the thermal energy view, you will see where the
    energy goes.

interactives.title: Conduction 3F: Temperatures inside walls
interactives.subtitle: How should you configure different layers for a wall for better insulation?
about: In this model, three layers (labeled as **A**, **B**, and **C**) that have different thermal conductivities
fill the space between the heater and an object.
**Your challenge is to find out which layer has the greatest thermal conductivity and which has the lowest
by running a sequence of tests for different layer configurations.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the four thermometers.
2.  Change the order of the layers using the drop-down menu to test a different setup.
3.  Repeat the above steps until you reach the conclusion.

interactives.title: Conduction 3G: Combine conductivity and heat capacity
interactives.subtitle: Which material provides the best insulation?
about: In this model, there are three test pieces made of materials that have different thermal conductivities and heat capacities.
**Your task is to find out which material is the best insulator.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the three thermometers.
2.  Choose *Thermal energy* from the **Heat map** drop-down list to switch the view from temperature distribution to
thermal energy distribution. In the thermal energy view, you will see where the energy goes.

interactives.title: Conduction 3H: Build your own layered wall
about: Try building your own wall using the objects provided. The conductor has ten times the conductivity
of the insulator. You can reshape them by clicking on them and dragging the small yellow rectangles.
Make sure that the pieces touch each other and bridge all the way from the heater on the left to the
object to be heated on the right.
You can build different walls by:
* moving the boxes around and changing their width and length (use your mouse to do this)
* copying and then pasting a box to create another one with the same properties (right-click
or control-click on the Mac, on an object to do this. You can then move and resize the new object.)
* making a sandwich of several layers in series
* making parallel connectors with different conductivities.
(For instance, imagine that the wall consists of insulation with an occasional metal stud that

forms a bridge through the insulation between
the inside and outside.)
You can place the extra thermometers anywhere you like if you want to measure the temperatures inside the wall.
Build at least two different walls in the middle space and compare their rates of heat flow.
You can compare two walls by turning on the graph, running the model for a minute, and noting
the temperature of the right-hand object.

interactives.title: Convection 4A: Natural convection
interactives.subtitle: Which mechanism transfers heat more quickly, conduction or convection?
about: This model has two parts with a warm surface at the bottom. The right-hand side is a solid material
that happens to have the same conductivity as air. The left-hand side is just air. Warmer air heated
by the hot surface has a buoyant force upward.
**Your task is to compare the rates of the heat flow from the bottom to the top in the two parts.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the thermometers and the temperature at
the bottom heater.
Reset the model. Set the bottom temperature to be **Low** and **High** and repeat steps 1-2, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4B: Slow down convection
interactives.subtitle: How can convection be reduced?
about: This model has two compartments with a warm surface at the bottom. In the middle of the
right-hand compartment there is a barrier.
**Your task is to compare the rates of the convective heat transfer from the bottom to the top in the two compartments.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the thermometers and the temperature at the bottom heater.
3.  Try changing the location of the barrier or adding more barriers. Click on the barrier to change size, move, or copy it.
4.  Try to connect what you observe in this model to the attic in a house.

interactives.title: Convection 4C: Forced convection
interactives.subtitle: How does blowing air cool down an object?
about: There are two warm objects in this model, separated by a thin, long insulator in the middle.
In the upper part, there is a fan blowing from left to right. In the lower part, there is no fan blowing.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  After the model has run for about 25 model minutes (the time for the model, not real time),
note the temperatures measured by the thermometers.
Set the wind speed to be **Low** and **High** and repeat steps 1-2, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4D: The stack effect
interactives.subtitle: Where does the house lose energy?
about: The two rooms each have a heater at the bottom and **leaks** near the top.
1.  Run the model and look for leaking energy.
2.  Click on the wall and roof elements to change the sizes and locations of the leaks.
3.  Note the convection pattern in each situation.

interactives.title: Convection 4E: Blowing wind
interactives.subtitle: Why should you close the windows in a stormy winter day?
about: This model investigates the effect of wind blowing towards a building. The air currents
are indicated by arrows and can be shown by streamlines.
1.  Run the model and note the convection and heating patterns both inside and outside the house,
heated by a heating board on the floor.
2.  Change the wind condition and open or close the windows to examine how heat flow will change.

interactives.title: Radiation 5A: Radiation energy and temperature
interactives.subtitle: Does a hotter object radiate more energy?
about: This model shows how two heat radiators at different temperatures warm up remote objects through radiation.
The dashed lines that will radiate out from the radiators represent invisible thermal radiation, which
passes energy across space. Two thermometers are used to measure the heat gains at the objects.
1.  Change the temperature of the left-hand side object using the radio buttons below the model.
2.  Compare the heating effect of the radiation at different temperatures.
3.  Reset the model each time you change the temperature of the left-hand side object.

interactives.title: Solar Energy 6D: Solar heating of a house
interactives.subtitle: How solar angle affect heating in a house?
about: This is a model of sunlight shining on a house with one window (white).
1.  Run the model and watch the house heat up.
2.  Change the sun angle by slider.
3.  Try different sun angles — a low angle (winter) and a high angle (summer).
4.  Turn off sunlight to see how the house loses heat (night condition).
5.  Be sure to reset the model between experiments.

interactives.title: Energy Detective 7A: Well and poorly-insulated houses
interactives.subtitle: Compare how much more heat a poorly-insulated house needs with a well-insulated one.
about: You can select one of two houses, A and B, which have identical shape as shown in the model but different quality of construction.
The yellow object in the middle of the house is a heater. Unlike the previous models, the temperature coloring is initially turned off.
You may turn it on using the **Heat map** radio button if it helps your diagnosis.
**Your task is to find which house requires higher power to heat.** Tryto maintain a temperature near the window
at about 20°C. Note that the heater has two power levels and can also be turned off and on as the model runs.

interactives.title: Energy Detective 7B: Where is the most heat lost?
interactives.subtitle: Use the temperature difference across walls to find the ones most poorly insulated.
about: This model house may have multiple locations that are poorly insulated.
**Your task is to use the two thermometers at the upper-left corner to detect where the house loses the heat the most.**
1.  Drag the thermometers around to record temperature data to help you find the energy-losing locations.
2.  There may be multiple locations that are poorly insulated. Compare your measurements and draw conclusions.

interactives.title: Energy Detective 7C: Vertical temperature gradients
interactives.subtitle: How does a ceiling effect the range of temperatures in a house?
about: This model shows the effect of natural convection in a house.
1.  Run the model and note the steady temperatures of the three thermometers, T1, T2, and T3, when the ceiling is present.
2.  Click the ceiling (the green piece) and move it entirely outside of the house.
3.  Note how the temperatures of the three thermometers change.

interactives.title: How does a Bolometer Work?
interactives.subtitle: Measuring the Power of Incident Electromagnetic Radiation Through the Heating of a Material
interactives.about:
A bolometer consists of a radiation absorber connected to a thermal
reservoir (a body of constant temperature) through a thermal conductor.
The radiation on the absorber raises its temperature above that of the
reservoir: The greater the radiation intensity, the more energy the
absorber absorbs, and the higher its temperature rises. Hence, a
bolometer can be used to measure radiation intensity.

interactives.title: Conservation of Energy
interactives.subtitle: How Accurate are Our Conduction Calculation?
interactives.about:
This simulation illustrates the accuracy of our heat solver by testing
how well it observes the Law of Conservation of Energy (aka the First
Law of Thermodynamics). The following model simulates a completely
insulative system (i.e., no heat in, no heat out) using a thermal
boundary of zero heat flux. As you can see, as the time step increases,
the precision decreases. But a small time step (0.01s) is capable of
maintaining the total thermal energy at a level as accurate as
**99.99%** for as long as the simulation runs, regardless of the
complexity of the structures in the system!

You may observe dark areas in interior walls in some old buildings. In

interactives.title: Heat & Temperature
interactives.subtitle: Computer Simulation: A Visual Approach to Learning the Invisible
interactives.about:
The change of thermal energy, or heat, Q in an object when its
temperature changes from T<sub>1</sub> to T<sub>2</sub> is

Q=ρVc(T<sub>2</sub>-T<sub>1</sub>)
{: .formula}

where *ρ* is the density, *V* is the volume, and *c* is the specific
heat.

Imagine an object is placed into a completely insulated box filled with
water (see the image below). The initial temperatures of the object and
the water may be different. The water will either warm up or cool down
through the diffusion of thermal energy. The direction of heat diffusion
depends on the difference of the initial temperatures. Two physical laws
dictate that the following things must happen:

The thermal energy that flows into or out of the water in the box is:

Q<sub>wat</sub>=ρ<sub>wat</sub>V<sub>wat</sub>c<sub>wat</sub>(T<sub>final</sub>-T<sub>wat</sub>)
{: .formula}

The thermal energy that out of or into the object is:

Q<sub>obj</sub>=ρ<sub>obj</sub>V<sub>obj</sub>c<sub>obj</sub>(T<sub>final</sub>-T<sub>obj</sub>)
{: .formula}

The Law of Conservation of Energy requires that
Q<sub>wat</sub>+Q<sub>obj</sub>=0. This allows us to determine that the
final temperature must be:

T<sub>final</sub>=
(ρ<sub>wat</sub>V<sub>wat</sub>c<sub>wat</sub>T<sub>wat</sub>+ρ<sub>obj</sub>V<sub>obj</sub>c<sub>obj</sub>T<sub>obj</sub>)/
(ρ<sub>wat</sub>V<sub>wat</sub>c<sub>wat</sub>+ρ<sub>obj</sub>V<sub>obj</sub>c<sub>obj</sub>)
{: .formula}

Computer modeling provides opportunities of virtual experimentation,
which could make the understanding of the above concepts more concrete.
The model below presents a dynamic view of how heat transfer actually
happens between the test piece and the water, as opposed to just
providing a value of final temperature.

In the model, there are two thermometers for monitoring the temperatures
inside and outside the test piece. While the model is running, you can
turn a graph on to view the temperatures recorded by the thermometers.
The following things can be explored with this model (remember to reset
the simulation using the \"Reset\" button before you change the model):

interactives.title: Lid-Driven Cavity
interactives.subtitle: Benchmark of Computational Fluid Dynamics
interactives.about:
The lid-driven cavity flow involves a fluid in a square box driven by
constant \"blow\" near the lid. Depending on the physical conditions, a
stable eddy can form within the box (as shown by the streamlines). You
may notice that when a stable eddy occupies the entire box, its center
is actually cooler than the edge, indicating the faster heat transfer
rate through forced convection than through conduction. The lid-driven
cavity problem is one of the most important benchmarks for computational
fluid dynamics.

Energy (*Q*) and power (*P*) are related by *Q* = *Pt*. This means the
longer (*t*) you turn on a heater, the more heat (*Q*) it will produce.
And the higher the power (*P*) is, the more heat (*Q*) it will produce.

Two identical, closed boxes each have a round heater at the center, with

graph on to monitor the temperatures; 2) Use the buttons at the
upper-right corner of the graph window to rescale the curves if
necessary; 3) Calculate **the ratio of the temperatures** measured by
the two thermometers in the two boxes and compare it with **the ratio of
the heating powers**.

interactives.title: The Prandtl Number
interactives.subtitle: Conductive vs. Convective Heat Transfer
interactives.about:
Both conduction and convection happen in fluids. As heat transfer
through both processes reduces the temperature difference, they can be
considered as competing against each other in transferring heat. There
are many different types of fluids, such as air, water, oil, or mercury.
The rates of conduction and convection vary in different fluids.
Sometimes, conduction dominates. Other times, convection dominates. The
Prandtl number is a parameter that can be used to roughly determine
which process will \"win\":

Pr=ν/α
{: .formula}

where *ν* is the kinematic viscosity and *α* is the thermal diffusivity.
If a fluid is more viscous (sticky), the Prandtl number is greater and
the heat transfer will be more conductive.

The following simulation shows how fluids with different Prandtl numbers
transfer heat.

interactives.title: Projection
interactives.about: * no further description available

interactives.title: Thermal Quadrupole
interactives.subtitle: Heat Flow from Four Sources in an Insulated Box

interactives.title: Radiation
interactives.about:
The total energy radiated by an object per unit time is proportional to
the fourth power of its absolute temperature *T* (in Kelvin, 0°C≈273K):

P=εσAT<sup>4</sup>
{: .formula}

where *A* is the surface area of the object, *σ* is the Stefan-Boltzmann
constant, and *ε* is the emissivity of the object\'s material. This is
known as the **Stefan-Boltzmann Law**.

The emissivities of materials vary. If the object is a perfect black
body, *ε*=1. Metals tend to have a very low emissivity. Water and paper,
on the other hand, have high emissivity (0.95).

The following model shows the temperature dependence of the radiation
power.

**Important Note:** Light radiation from the hot plate is represented by
a limited number of rays, each of which travels at a much slower speed
than the speed of light. This is a computational approximation that does
not reflect the nature of light energy.

interactives.title: Rectangular vs. Round Heat Source
interactives.subtitle: Why does Temperature Drop Faster near a Round Heat Source?
interactives.about:
A rectangular heat source (that is almost as long as the edge of the
upper compartment) and a round heat source are both at 80°C. At the left
side there are two heat sinks set at 20°C. The entire boundary is
insulative. The heat flux vectors (the rates of heat flow at given
locations) appear to be much greater near the round heat source than
near the rectangular one, indicating that temperature drops faster in
the former case. The heat flux field in the case of the rectangular heat
source appears to be uniform, with the temperature drops one degree at
approximately the same distance away from the heat source. Can you
figure out why there is such a difference? (Hint: Think about
conservation of energy during heat flow.)

interactives.title: Regulating Temperature
interactives.about:
Two closed boxes have identical heaters but the heat capacity of the
left-hand box is much greater than the heat capacity of the right-hand
box. The power switch controls both heaters.

interactives.title: The Reynolds Number
interactives.subtitle: Laminar Flow vs. Turbulent Flow
interactives.about:
In fluid mechanics, the Reynolds number Re is a dimensionless number
that gives a measure of the ratio of inertial forces to viscous forces
and consequently quantifies the relative importance of these two types
of forces for given flow conditions:

Re=VL<sub>c</sub>/ν
{: .formula}

where *ν* is the kinematic viscosity, *V* is the mean velocity of the
fluid, and *L*<sub>c</sub> is the characteristic length of the geometry.
The higher the Reynolds number is, the more turbulent the flow will be.
The following simulation compares four different Reynolds numbers. The
fluid is the same in the four separate flow channels, but the driving
velocities are different. The viscosity of the fluid can be altered
using a slider.

interactives.title: What is Modeling?
interactives.subtitle: Simulating Natural Phenomena with Computers
interactives.about:
Most phenomena involved in physical systems are governed by well-defined
scientific laws. These laws correlate different properties and provide
insights to the states of a system and processes it undergoes.
Mathematical models can therefore be derived based on the laws, allowing
scientists and engineers to explain what has happened or predict what
will happen.

If a mathematical model is too complicated to solve, a computer will be
needed. Thus, we have a **computational model** that approximates the
solution using some numerical algorithms. Computational models are now
increasingly important parts of computer-aided design (CAD) packages,
which are in the tool box of almost every engineer whose job involves
research and development (R&D). Computational models are often
called **numerical simulations**. So we will use the two terms
interchangably.

Today\'s students need to have a fundamental understanding of what
computational models are and how they can be used to accelerate R&D
processes.

The following is a simple model of solar heating of a house. Use the
controls to play with it and explore how such a model contributes to
developing an understanding of the physical variables and processes
involved in designing solar houses.

<input type="button" value="Reload page"

interactives.title: Solar Updraft Tower
interactives.subtitle: A New Solar Power Technology
interactives.about:
The solar updraft tower is a clean energy power plant for generating
electricity from the sun. Sunshine falling on a greenhouse collector
structure around the base of a tall chimney heats the air within it. The
resulting convection causes air to rise up in the tower, driving wind
turbines to produce electricity. In December 2011, Hyperion Energy
announced that it would build a solar updraft tower in Arizona that
would rival the height of the tallest building in the world!

Right-click these links to download the models:  
 [solar-updraft-tower.e2d](e2d/solar-updraft-tower.e2d),
[solar-updraft-tower2.e2d](e2d/solar-updraft-tower2.e2d),
[solar-updraft-tower3.e2d](e2d/solar-updraft-tower3.e2d)
{: align="center"}

interactives.title: Stack Effect
interactives.subtitle: How does Infilstration Cause Buildings to Lose Energy due to Convection?
interactives.about:
Also known as the chimney effect, the stack effect is the movement of
air in and out a structure driven by natural thermal convection (i.e.,
hot air rises and cool air sinks). The effect usually causes the system
to lose energy more quickly, as the following simulation shows.

interactives.title: Test Links
interactives.subtitle: Multiple Simulations Can Be Linked Together in Energy2D
interactives.about:
To support the full screen mode, Energy2D provides a small control panel
on which you can define links to the previous simulation and the next
simulation. With this functionality, you can load a new simulation into
Energy2D without leaving the page and provide a sequence of linked
simulations that are related to a topic.

interactives.title: How the Sun Affects a Thermostat
interactives.subtitle: How Much Energy Can be Saved for Heating When the Sun Shines?
interactives.about:
A thermostat is a controller that maintains a system\'s temperature near
a fixed point. The simplest thermostat does this by switching a heater
or AC on and off to maintain the desired temperature. The following
model simulates a thermostat that uses a temperature sensor to control a
heater. Turn on the temperature graph. Let the simulation run for a few
cycles and then turn on the sunlight. Compare the behavior of the
temperature graph. You can also try to move the temperature sensor to
examine how the on/off time of the thermostat depends on its location.

interactives.title: Solar Heating and Thermostats
interactives.subtitle: How does Solar Heating Affect the Duty Cycle of a Thermostat?
interactives.about:
Note: This simulation starts at 12am and assumes that the sun rises at
4am and sets at 8pm. So in the first few seconds you may not see
heating. Just wait for a while until the sun shines in.

interactives.title: Trombe Wall
interactives.subtitle: An Air Convective Loop that Circulates Solar Energy
interactives.about:
A Trombe wall is a sun-facing wall separated from the outdoors by glass
and an air space, which absorbs solar energy and releases it into the
house through a convective air loop. It consists a solar absorber (often
painted black) and two vents for air to circulate and carry the solar
heat. The following simulation shows this.

Right-click these links to download the models:  
 [trombe-wall.e2d](e2d/trombe-wall.e2d),
[trombe-wall-closeup.e2d](e2d/trombe-wall-closeup.e2d)
{: align="center"}

interactives.title: Two Blocks
interactives.subtitle: What Really Makes the Sense of Warmth or Coldness?
interactives.about:
The amount of heat transferred from an object to your hand or vice versa
determines what you really feel when you touch it. The model uses two
contacting objects at different temperatures to simulate the heat
transfer of touch. The amount of heat transferred between them depends
on a number of factors that you will explore with this simulation.

interactives.title: Vortex Street
interactives.subtitle: The Effect of Obstacle Size
interactives.about:
The term vortex street (also known as von Kármán vortex street) is used
in fluid dynamics to describe a repeating pattern of swirling vortices
caused by the unsteady separation of flow over obstacles. This
simulation shows that the formation of a vortex street depends on the
diameter of the obstacle.

interactives.title: The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics
interactives.subtitle: If two systems are in thermal equilibrium with a third one, they are also in thermal equilibrium with each other.
interactives.about:
If A and B are in thermal equilibrium with C, then A and B will be in
thermal equilibrium with each other if they are brought into contact.

interactives.title: Heat Storage 1A: Measuring heat storage
interactives.subtitle: Why does a warm object feel warm when you touch it?
interactives.about:
The model shows two contacting objects that have identical mass (*m*)
and specific heat (*c*<sub>p</sub>) but different initial temperatures.
The amount of heat transferred between them measures the heat initially
stored in the warmer object.

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary. Click on a thermometer to highlight
    its data.
4.  Wait until the temperatures of the two objects do not change any
    further.
5.  Record the final temperature of the two objects in your workbook.

**Click the Reset button** and change the initial temperatures of the
two objects using the drop-down menus below the model. Repeat steps 1-5
for two more different temperature setups.

interactives.title: Heat Storage 1B: Heat storage depends on specific heat
interactives.subtitle: Why do some materials take longer to heat up or cool down than others?
interactives.about:
How much heat is stored in an object depends on its specific heat, as
described by the formula below:



| *Q* = <font color="red">***c*<sub>p</sub>***m*(*T*<sub>final</sub>-*T*<sub>initial</sub>) </font>

 |
{: cellpadding="10" border="0" bgcolor="#ffffff"}

This model is similar to 1A, except that the specific heats of the two
rectangular objects are different.

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  Wait until the temperatures of the two objects do not change any
    further.
5.  Record the final temperature of the two objects in your workbook.

**Click the Reset button** and change the specific heats of the two
objects using the drop-down menus below the model. Repeat steps 1-5 for
two more different setups. Make sure that the specific heats are
different in each setup.

interactives.title: Heat Storage 1C: Heat storage depends on size
interactives.subtitle: Why does a bigger house need more energy to heat?
interactives.about:
How much heat stored in an object depends on its mass, or size, as
described by the formula below:



| *Q* = *c*<sub>p</sub><font color="red">***m***(*T*<sub>final</sub>-*T*<sub>initial</sub>) </font>

 |
{: cellpadding="10" border="0" bgcolor="#ffffff"}

Note that the specific heats of the two rectangular objects are
different. **Your task is to change the size of one or both
objects—hence the mass—so that the equilibrium temperature will be
approximately 25°C.**

1.  To change the size of an object, click and drag the small yellow
    rectangles at its edges.
2.  **Make sure that the objects still touch each other but do not
    overlap and there is a thermometer in each object.**
3.  Run the model and wait until the temperatures do not change any
    further.
4.  If the final temperatures are close to 25°C (within 1°C), write down
    the sizes of the objects in your workbook.
5.  Otherwise, click the Reset button, resize the objects, and run the
    model again until the final temperatures are close to 25°C (within
    1°C).

You may use the grid and the ruler as visual assistance when you drag
the rectangles.

Use the drop-down menu under the model to change to a different setup of
specific heats and repeat the task.

interactives.title: Power and Energy 2A: Regulating temperature
interactives.subtitle: Why does the temperature in a box change more dramatically than the temperature in the other?
interactives.about:
Two closed boxes have identical heaters but the heat capacity of the
left-hand box is much greater than the heat capacity of the right-hand
box. The power switch controls both heaters.

1.  Run the model and turn the graph on to monitor the temperatures.
    Click on a thermometer to highlight its data.
2.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
3.  When the **left-hand side box** reaches 5°C, turn off the power.
4.  Try to keep the temperature in the **left-hand side box** between 3
    and 5°C by turning the power on and off.
5.  Compare the shapes of the two temperature curves.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3A: Heat conduction through materials
interactives.subtitle: Which material conducts heat most quickly?
interactives.about:
In this model, you will compare heat conduction through four different
types of materials: metal, stone, fiberglass, and wood.

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the four
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary. Click on a thermometer to highlight
    its data.
4.  Wait until the temperatures do not change any further.
5.  In which material does heat flow the fastest? Answer the questions
    in your workbook.

In the following sections, we will study all the factors that affect the
rate of heat conduction.

interactives.title: Conduction 3B: The effect of thermal conductivity
interactives.subtitle: Which test piece has higher thermal conductivity?
interactives.about:
The rate of heat conduction depends on the thermal conductivity of the
material (*k*), as described in the formula below:



| Δ*Q*/Δ*t* = -<font color="red">***k****A*Δ*T*/*L* </font>

 |
{: cellpadding="10" border="0" bgcolor="#ffffff"}

(This formula says that heat transfer rate is proportional to thermal
conductivity. See the Workbook for the meanings of the math symbols.)

This model has two situations for you to compare. On the left are two
separate heat sources with a constant temperature (50°C). On the right
are two separate objects with a thermometer, which measures how much
heat has been conducted. The left-hand side and right-hand side objects
are connected by two test pieces that differ in only thermal
conductivity (*k*). **Your task is to tell which test piece has higher
thermal conductivity.**

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  Click a thermometer to highlight its temperature curve.

After you have observed the model, answer the questions in your
workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3C: The effect of wall thickness
interactives.subtitle: Which wall loses thermal energy more quickly, thick or thin?
interactives.about:
The rate of heat conduction depends on how far heat has to travel (*L*), as described below:
ΔQ/Δt = -kAΔT/L

(This formula says that the heat transfer rate is inversely proportional to the distance heat has to travel.)

This model has two situations for you to compare. On the left are two separate heat sources with a constant temperature. On the right are two separate objects with a thermometer that measures how much heat has been conducted. The upper test piece is twice as long as the lower one. Both are made of the same material. This would be like a thick wall compared to a thin one.

  1. Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
  2. Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
  3. Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to rescale the curves if necessary.

After you observe the model, answer the questions in your workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3D: The effect of temperature difference
interactives.subtitle: Does a hotter object lose heat more quickly?
interactives.about:
**Your task is to investigate how the amount of heat conducted through
the test piece depends on the temperature of the heater on the left-hand
side:**



| Δ*Q*/Δ*t* = -*k**A*<font color="red">**Δ*T***/*L* </font>

 |
{: cellpadding="10" border="0" bgcolor="#ffffff"}

1.  Run the model until it stops.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the change of the temperature if
    necessary.
3.  In the workbook, write down the temperature of the heater and the
    temperature of the thermometer when the model stops.
4.  Use the drop-down menu below the model to change the heater
    temperature.
5.  Repeat 1-3 for two more different heater temperatures.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3E: Combine thermal conductivity and heat capacity
interactives.subtitle: Which material provides the best insulation?
interactives.about:
In this model, there are three test pieces made of materials that have
different thermal conductivities and heat capacities. **Your task is to
find out which material is the best insulator.**

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the three
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  Choose \"Thermal energy\" from the \"Heat map\" drop-down list to
    switch the view from temperature distribution to thermal energy
    distribution. In the thermal energy view, you will see where the
    energy goes.

After you observe the model, answer the questions in your workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3F: Temperatures inside walls
interactives.subtitle: How should you configure different layers for a wall for better insulation?
interactives.about:
In this model, three layers (labeled as \"A\", \"B\", and \"C\") that
have different thermal conductivities fill the space between the heater
and an object. **Your challenge is to find out which layer has the
greatest thermal conductivity and which has the lowest by running a
sequence of tests for different layer configurations.**

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the four
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  Change the order of the layers using the drop-down menu to test a
    different setup.
5.  Repeat the above steps until you reach the conclusion.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3G: Combine thermal conductivity and heat capacity
interactives.subtitle: Which material provides the best insulation?
interactives.about:
In this model, there are three test pieces made of materials that have
different thermal conductivities and heat capacities. **Your task is to
find out which material is the best insulator.**

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the three
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  Choose \"Thermal energy\" from the \"Heat map\" drop-down list to
    switch the view from temperature distribution to thermal energy
    distribution. In the thermal energy view, you will see where the
    energy goes.

After you observe the model, answer the questions in your workbook.

interactives.title: Conduction 3H: Build your own layered wall (Optional)
interactives.about:
Try building your own wall using the objects provided. The conductor has
ten times the conductivity of the insulator. You can reshape them by
clicking on them and dragging the small yellow rectangles. Make sure
that the pieces touch each other and bridge all the way from the heater
on the left to the object to be heated on the right.

You can build different walls by:

* moving the boxes around and changing their width and length (use your
  mouse to do this);
* copying and then pasting a box to create another one with the same
  properties (right-click, or control-click on the Mac, on an object to
  do this. You can then move and resize the new object.);
* making a sandwich of several layers in series;
* making parallel connectors with different conductivities.

(For instance, imagine that the wall consists of insulation with an
occasional metal stud that forms a bridge through the insulation between
the inside and outside.)

You can place the extra thermometers anywhere you like if you want to
measure the temperatures inside the wall.

Build at least two different walls in the middle space and compare their
rates of heat flow. You can compare two walls by turning on the graph,
running the model for a minute, and noting the temperature of the
right-hand object.

**For Windows users: Take a screenshot of your wall using the \"Print
Screen\" key on your keyboard (you may hold down the Ctrl key), paste
into the Paint program and save it as an image file in your folder.**

Then answer the questions in your workbook.

interactives.title: Convection 4A: Natural convection
interactives.subtitle: Which mechanism transfers heat more quickly, conduction or convection?
interactives.about:
This model has two parts with a warm surface at the bottom. The
right-hand side is a solid material that happens to have the same
conductivity as air. The left-hand side is just air. Warmer air heated
by the hot surface has a buoyant force upward. **Your task is to compare
the rates of the heat flow from the bottom to the top in the two
parts.**

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary. Click on a thermometer to highlight
    its data.
4.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the
    thermometers and the temperature at the bottom heater in your
    workbook.

Reset the model. Set the bottom temperature to be \"Low\" and \"High\"
and repeat steps 1-4, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4B: Slow down convection
interactives.subtitle: How can convection be reduced?
interactives.about:
This model has two compartments with a warm surface at the bottom. In
the middle of the right-hand compartment there is a barrier. **Your task
is to compare the rates of the convective heat transfer from the bottom
to the top in the two compartments.**

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary. Click on a thermometer to highlight
    its data.
4.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the
    thermometers and the temperature at the bottom heater in your
    workbook.
5.  Try changing the location of the barrier or adding more barriers.
    Click on the barrier to change size, move, or copy it.
6.  Try to connect what you observe in this model to the attic in a
    house.

interactives.title: Convection 4C: Forced convection
interactives.subtitle: How does blowing air cool down an object?
interactives.about:
There are two warm objects in this model, separated by a thin, long
insulator in the middle. In the upper part, there is a fan blowing from
left to right. In the lower part, there is no fan blowing.

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  After the model has run for about 0.4 model hour (the time for the
    model, not real time), write the temperatures measured by the
    thermometers in your workbook.

Set the wind speed to be \"Low\" and \"High\" and repeat steps 1-4,
respectively.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Convection 4D: The stack effect
interactives.subtitle: Where does the house lose energy?
interactives.about:
The two rooms each have a heater at the bottom and \"leaks\" near the
top.

1.  Run the model and look for leaking energy.
2.  Click on the wall and roof elements and drag the small yellow
    rectangles on their edges to change the sizes and locations of the
    leaks.
3.  Note the convection pattern in each situation.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Convection 4E: Blowing wind
interactives.subtitle: Why should you close the windows in a stormy winter day?
interactives.about:
This model investigates the effect of wind blowing towards a building.
The air currents are indicated by arrows and can be shown by
streamlines.

1.  Run the model and note the convection and heating patterns both
    inside and outside the house, heated by a heating board on the
    floor.
2.  Change the wind condition and open or close the windows to examine
    how heat flow will change.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Radiation 5A: Radiation energy depends on temperature
interactives.subtitle: Does a hotter object radiate more energy?
interactives.about:
This model shows how two heat radiators at different temperatures warm
up remote objects through radiation. The dashed lines that will radiate
out from the radiators represent invisible thermal radiation, which
passes energy across space. Two thermometers are used to measure the
heat gains at the objects.

1.  Turn the graph on to monitor the change of temperatures.
2.  Change the temperature of the left-hand side object using the radio
    buttons below the model.
3.  Compare the heating effect of the radiation at different
    temperatures.
4.  Reset the model each time you change the temperature of the
    left-hand side object.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Solar Energy 6D: Solar heating of a house
interactives.about:
This is a model of sunlight shining on a house with one window (white).

1.  Run the model and watch the house heat up.
2.  Change the sun angle by pressing on the \'Q\' or \'W\' on the
    keyboard.
3.  Try different sun angles — a low angle (winter) and a high angle
    (summer).
4.  Turn off sunlight to see how the house loses heat (night condition).
5.  Be sure to reset the model between experiments.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Energy Detective 7A: A well-insulated house vs. a poorly-insulated house
interactives.about:
You can select one of two houses, A and B, which have identical shape as
shown in the model but different quality of construction. The yellow
object in the middle of the house is a heater. Unlike the previous
models, the temperature coloring is initially turned off. You may turn
it on using the \"Heat map\" radio button if it helps your diagnosis.

**Your task is to find which house requires higher power to heat.** Try
to maintain a temperature near the window at about 20°C. Note that the
heater has two power levels and can also be turned off and on as the
model runs. Turn on the graph to observe the temperatures recorded by
the thermometers.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Energy Detective 7B: Where does this house lose heat the most?
interactives.about:
This model house may have multiple locations that are poorly insulated.
**Your task is to use the two thermometers at the upper-left corner to
detect where the house loses the heat the most.**

1.  Drag the thermometers around to record temperature data to help you
    find the energy-losing locations.
2.  There may be multiple locations that are poorly insulated. Compare
    your measurements and draw conclusions.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook. Each building section is labeled so that you can refer to
it in your answers.

interactives.title: Energy Detective 7C: Discover a vertical temperature gradient
interactives.about:
This model shows the effect of natural convection in a house.

1.  Run the model, turn the graph on, and observe the temperatures.
2.  Record the steady temperatures of the three thermometers, T1, T2,
    and T3, when the ceiling is present.
3.  Click the ceiling (the green piece) and press the DELETE key on your
    keyboard to remove it.
4.  Record the temperatures of the three thermometers again.

You may turn the streamlines on to observe the convective flow in more
details.

After you have completed your investigation, answer the questions in
your workbook.

interactives.title: Geniverse Gene to Protein
about: Geniverse Gene to Protein Genie

interactives.title: Pendulum: rod length and mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the factors of rod length and mass affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Adjust the **Rod length**, **Mass of the ball** and **Starting angle** parameters.
Then click the **Start** button to start an experiment run. Watch the **Pendulum Angle**
graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it swings back and forth.
Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Try changing each parameter
and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
After closing this window click the **?** help icon in the upper left to find out more.

interactives.title: Pendulum 180: rod length and mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the factors of starting angles up to 180°, rod length and mass affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Adjust the **Rod length**, **Mass of the ball** and **Starting angle** parameters.
Then click the **Start** button to start an experiment run. Watch the **Pendulum Angle**
graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it swings back and forth.
Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Try changing each parameter
and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
After closing this window click the **?** help icon in the upper left to find out more.

interactives.title: Double Pendulum
interactives.subtitle: Explore a double pendulum.
about: Adjust the **Rod length**, **Mass of the ball** and **Starting angle** parameters.
Then click the **Start** button to start an experiment run. Watch the **Pendulum Angle**
graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it swings back and forth.
Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Try changing each parameter
and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
After closing this window click the **?** help icon in the upper left to find out more.

interactives.title: Pendulum
interactives.subtitle: Explore some factors that affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it
swings back and forth. Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Adjust the
scale by dragging the numbers on the axes. Change each variable – gravity, rod length,
starting angle and mass – and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
Try the damping slider. Does damping change the period?

interactives.title: Spring and Mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore some factors that affect the period of a spring.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graph to see how the height of the mass changes as
it moves up and down. Use the graph to determine the period of the mass-spring system.
Adjust the scale by dragging the numbers on the axes. Change each variable – gravity,
spring constant, starting distance and mass – and observe how each one affects the period.
Can you explain why? Is this different from the relationships for a pendulum? Try the
damping slider. Does damping change the period?

interactives.title: Pendulum and Spring
interactives.subtitle: Explore the motion of a pendulum on a spring.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graphs to see the motion of the spring pendulum.
Can you distinguish the pattern of spring motion (up and down) from the pattern
of pendulum motion (back and forth)? How are the two related? Is there a regular
pattern to the motion? Compare the periods of the two graphs. How many different
patterns can you produce by changing the variables – gravity, rod length, mass and
spring constant? Under what conditions does the energy switch between back and forth
and up and down? Does the initial starting angle affect the patterns when all the
other variables are unchanged?

interactives.title: Distance and Force Magnitude
interactives.subtitle: Explore the relationship between the electric field around an object and the forces on charged objects.
about: Control the polarity of the stationary charged object and observe how it affects the electric field around the charged object.
Add a second charged object and move it around the stationary object.
Observe how the strength and direction of the forces depends on the charges and distance between the two objects.
Turn the force and electric field visualizations on and off to see their interactions.

interactives.title: Charge Intensity and Electric Field Force Magnitude
interactives.subtitle: Manipulate the charge on objects to explore the relationship between the electric field around objects and the forces on objects.
about: Control the amount of chrage on two objects an observe how it affects
(1) the electric fields around the charged objects and
(2) the strength and direction of the forces acting between the two objects.
Turn the force and electric field visualizations on and off to see their interactions.

interactives.title: Opposites Attract
interactives.subtitle: Explore how charged objects interact.
interactives.about: Change the charge on each sphere to positive or negative. Observe how the charges affect the interaction between the spheres.

interactives.title: Direction of Force in Electric Fields
interactives.subtitle: How is the direction of force oriented between charged objects?
about: An electric field is produced by the stationary object in this simulation.
How does the force on the draggable object change when it is moved around the stationary object?
How the force affected by the polarity of the charge on the stationary object?
Use the *trace force vectors* checkbox to help characterize the direction of force arrow when the charged object is in different positions.

interactives.title: Direction of Force Around a VDG (Negatively Charged)
interactives.subtitle: How is the direction of force oriented between charged objects?
about: The colored arrow indicates the direction of force between the charged object and the VDG.
How does the orientation of the arrow change as the charged object is moved around?
Use the *trace force vectors* checkbox to help characterize the direction of force arrow when the charged object is in different positions

interactives.title: Direction of Force Around a VDG (Positively Charged)
interactives.subtitle: How is the direction of force oriented between charged objects?
about: The colored arrow indicates the direction of force between the charged object and the VDG.
How does the orientation of the arrow change as the charged object is moved around?
Use the *trace force vectors* checkbox to help characterize the direction of force arrow when the charged object is in different positions

interactives.title: Direction and Strength of Force in Electric Fields
interactives.subtitle: Explore the force between charged objects.
about: An electric field is produced by the stationary object in this simulation.
How does the force on the draggable object change when it is moved around the stationary object?
How the force affected by the polarity of the charge on the stationary object?
Use the *trace force vectors* checkbox to help characterize the direction and magnitude of force arrow when the charged object is in different positions.

interactives.title: Electrostatics: Maze Game
interactives.subtitle: Guide a charged object through a maze.
interactives.about: Control the charge of the gray ball by using the -, 0, and + buttons below the game. Use the attractive and repulsive forces between charged objects to navigate through the maze. Can you get it to the target before time runs out?

interactives.title: Mixing Liquids
interactives.subtitle: Explore how liquids mix at the molecular level.

interactives.title: Target Game (Free Play)
interactives.subtitle: Can you steer a charged particle to a target by using charged objects?
about: Use the *Launch a positive particle* button to shoot a positive particle across the game board.
Place any number of charged objects in any location to steer the positive particle to the target.
Can you get the charged particle into the target?

interactives.title: Target Game (Charge Magnitude / Force Relationship)
interactives.subtitle: Can you manipulate the amount of charge on charged objects to steer a charged particle to a target?
about: Use the *Launch a positive particle* button to shoot a positive particle across the game board.
Adjust the amount of charge on objects **A** and **B** to steer the moving particle to the target.
Can you get the charged particle into the target?

interactives.title: Target Game (Distance/Force Relationship)
interactives.subtitle: Can you manipulate the position of charged particles to steer another object to a target?
about: Use the *Launch a positive particle* button to shoot a positive particle across the game board.
Adjust the position of the negatively and positively charged objects to steer the moving particle to the target.

interactives.title: Crystals: Introduction to crystals - Far and Near Atoms (MOLO)
Convection 4A: Natural convection
interactives.subtitle: Which mechanism transfers heat more quickly, conduction or convection?
about: This model has two parts with a warm surface at the bottom. The right-hand side is a solid material
that happens to have the same conductivity as air. The left-hand side is just air. Warmer air heated
by the hot surface has a buoyant force upward.
**Your task is to compare the rates of the heat flow from the bottom to the top in the two parts.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the thermometers and the temperature at
the bottom heater.
Reset the model. Set the bottom temperature to be **Low** and **High** and repeat steps 1-2, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4B: Slow down convection
interactives.subtitle: How can convection be reduced?
about: This model has two compartments with a warm surface at the bottom. In the middle of the
right-hand compartment there is a barrier.
**Your task is to compare the rates of the convective heat transfer from the bottom to the top in the two compartments.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the thermometers and the temperature at the bottom heater.
3.  Try changing the location of the barrier or adding more barriers. Click on the barrier to change size, move, or copy it.
4.  Try to connect what you observe in this model to the attic in a house.

interactives.title: Convection 4C: Forced convection
interactives.subtitle: How does blowing air cool down an object?
about: There are two warm objects in this model, separated by a thin, long insulator in the middle.
In the upper part, there is a fan blowing from left to right. In the lower part, there is no fan blowing.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  After the model has run for about 25 model minutes (the time for the model, not real time),
note the temperatures measured by the thermometers.
Set the wind speed to be **Low** and **High** and repeat steps 1-2, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4D: The stack effect
interactives.subtitle: Where does the house lose energy?
about: The two rooms each have a heater at the bottom and **leaks** near the top.
1.  Run the model and look for leaking energy.
2.  Click on the wall and roof elements to change the sizes and locations of the leaks.
3.  Note the convection pattern in each situation.

interactives.title: Convection 4E: Blowing wind
interactives.subtitle: Why should you close the windows in a stormy winter day?
about: This model investigates the effect of wind blowing towards a building. The air currents
are indicated by arrows and can be shown by streamlines.
1.  Run the model and note the convection and heating patterns both inside and outside the house,
heated by a heating board on the floor.
2.  Change the wind condition and open or close the windows to examine how heat flow will change.

interactives.title: Conduction B - area
interactives.subtitle: How does Conducting Area Affect Conduction Rate?
interactives.about:
The following model compares heat conduction through two test pieces
made of identical material but their conducting areas are different.

interactives.title: Conduction D - Heat Capacity
interactives.subtitle: How does Specific Heat Affect Conduction Rate?
interactives.about:
The following model compares heat conduction through two test pieces
that differ ONLY in specific heat. Choosing \"Thermal energy\" in the
\"Heat map\" drop-down list will provide an explanation of the
dependence of heat conduction rate on specific heat.

interactives.title: Conduction C: Temperature Difference
interactives.subtitle: How does Temperature Difference Affect Conduction Rate?
interactives.about:
If the fire under a frying pan is more intense, will your hand feel
hotter?

![Skillet over an intense flame.](_assets/img/skillet-more-flame.jpg)
![Skillet over a low flame.](_assets/img/skillet-less-flame.jpg)
{: align="center"}

The following model compares heat conduction through two identical test
pieces but the temperature differences across them are different.

interactives.title: Conduction A - wood vs metal
interactives.subtitle: Thermal Conductivity: The Ability to Conduct Heat
interactives.about:
Which conducts heat more quickly from a frying pan to your hand, a wood
handle or a metal one?

![Skillet with a wood handle being heated over open
flame.](_assets/img/skillet-conductivity-low.jpg) ![Skillet with a metal
handle being heated over open
flame.](_assets/img/skillet-conductivity-high.jpg)
{: align="center"}

The following model compares heat conduction through two materials of
different thermal conductivities.

interactives.title: Pressure Equilibrium
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: There are gases on both sides of a moveable barrier (piston), which stays in the same place
(more or less) when you run the model because the gas pressure on the piston is in equilibrium.
Add purple gas molecules and watch what happens to the piston. Reset the model. Now add
yellow gas molecules. What happens to the piston?
Try heating or cooling the gas molecules. Explain the change in equilibrium with each
change. Which has a greater effect on equilibrium -- changing the number of gas molecules
or changing the temperature? Why?

interactives.title: Collapsing Soda Can
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: The model is an incomplete model of a soda can.
Currently it is showing gas molecules inside and outside the soda can before it is plunged in ice water.
The rectangle in the middle of the model represents a micro-section of the soda can wall.
Design a model that shows what happens after the can is placed in ice water.
Use the tools on the sides of the model to more accurately represent the experiment.
Use tools to heat and cool the molecules where it is appropriate.

interactives.title: Intermolecular Attractions and States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Explore how states of matter are related to the strength of intermolecular attractions.
about: There are three states of matter—solid, liquid and gas. Run the model and change the
strength of attractions between the molecules. How does changing the force of attraction
between molecules affect the state of that material?

interactives.title: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Melting Experiment
about: Specific heat capacitiy is the measure of the heat energy required
to raise the temperature of a given quantity of a substance by one
kelvin. Latent heat of melting describes tœhe amount of heat
required to melt a solid. When a solid is undergoing melting, the
temperature basically remains constant until the entire solid is
molten. The above simulation demonstrates the specific heat and
the latent heat.
The physical origin of latent heat is that when a system is in a
phase transition, its structure will change. Changing structure
usually results in changes of potential energy, because potential
energy depends primarily on structure. In the simulation,
the energy added to the system is absorbed by the atoms and used
to break the interatomic interactions (so that they can leave the
condensed state). During the phase transition the kinetic energy
doesn't increase, as the
potential energy increases in the expense of the input energy.
During this period, the interatomic interactions diminish and the
structure breaks up, resulting in a phase transition.
One thing you would notice is that the temperature-energy curve on
the right has fluctuations. This is because we have much fewer
atoms (169) in the simulation than there would be in a real
physical model.

interactives.title: Specific Heat and Latent Heat in Condensation
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Condensation Experiment
about: Specific heat capacitiy is the measure of the heat energy required
to raise the temperature of a given quantity of a substance by one
kelvin. Latent heat of melting describes tœhe amount of heat
required to melt a solid. When a solid is undergoing melting, the

the latent heat.

interactives.title: Phase Changes Caused by Energy Input
interactives.subtitle: Explore how energy input causes matter to change states.
about: Matter exists as solids, liquids and gases, and can change state between these.
The model shows a liquid material on the left (small atoms). The amount of heat
energy is shown by kinetic energy (KE) shading, with deeper shades of red
representing more energetic atoms. On the right side of the barrier is a solid
material (large atoms).
Run the model. How much energy is able to penetrate the barrier? Remove the barrier.
How quickly do the more energetic atoms melt the solid?

interactives.title: Custom Component Dimensions
interactives.subtitle: Graph, Bar Graph, Slider, Button and Text can have custom dimensions specified using 'width' and 'height' properties (all CSS values are accepted).

interactives.title: Oil and Water: ar: 1.3, fontScale 1.5
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water don’t mix." But why? Run the model of
polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water
mixture," then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Oil and Water: 1.3, smaller model
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water don’t mix." But why? Run the model of
polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water
mixture," then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Oil and Water: 1.3
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water don’t mix." But why? Run the model of

interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.

polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water

interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water don’t mix." But why? Run the model of
polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water
mixture," then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Replacing Bitmap Images with SVG
interactives.subtitle: Experiments replacing bitmap images with SVG documents to preserve quality when scaled up.
about: This Interactive displays an image with a suggestion for how to start using the Interactive.
Current possible images including the SVG replacements for the png image:
1. [instructionBox.png](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted/layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox.png)
This is a 253x58 pixel png image. Will appear pixelated when scaled to larger sizes.
2. [instructionBox.svg](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted/layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox.svg)
Created with Adobe Illustrator this SVG image uses an embedded base64 image for the drop-shadow effect.
Additionally explicit paths are used to draw the text instead of using SVG text objects, this makes the text
rendering independent of whether a specific font is installed on the users computer.
3. [instructionBox2.svg](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted//layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox2.svg)
Created using the open-source Inkscape application this SVG image uses SVG text elements and does not have a drop shadow.
4. [instructionBox3.svg](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted//layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox3.svg)
Created by hand, this SVG image uses SVG text elements and the SVG feGaussianBlur filter to create the drop-shadow effect.
